Situation1: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: Tax documents are organized a month before the deadline, and a free vaccine clinic runs this weekend at the community center.
Story: The phone pressed against my ear, I listened as Mr. Jenkins, a long-time customer, raised his voice, demanding to know why our latest offer sounded suspiciously like a scam. My script urged me to stay calm, answer every objection, and keep him on the line. I could almost hear my supervisor’s voice in my head: “Don’t let them hang up. Address every concern.” But as I tried to reassure Mr. Jenkins, my mind wandered to the envelope of tax documents waiting on my kitchen table—organized, but not yet filed. The community center’s vaccine clinic was this weekend, and I’d promised myself I’d go, do my part for public health. The pressure built inside me: the company needed me to be the perfect telemarketer, but my conscience nagged at me to be a responsible citizen. I felt torn, my words to Mr. Jenkins faltering as I wrestled with the demands of both roles, unsure which responsibility should come first.
